awd_titl_txt: SBES TWC: Phase: Small: Protecting the Bazaar: The Ecology of Cybersecurity in Weakly Fortified Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
While policy interest and empirical research on cyber attacks have both increased substantially in recent years, very little attention has been focused on the local ecology of actively operating computer networks.   In the research proposed we focus on a bazaar computing environment (i.e. weakly fortified computer networks where a wide variety of users engage in a range of activities with minimal security in largely unregulated settings) and seek to answer three broad research questions: (1) can users within bazaar environments be educated to engage in less risky on-line behavior?  (2) can hackers within bazaar environments be deterred through available options? and (3) if users can be educated and hackers can be deterred  what is the optimal environment in which IT management can maximize education of users and deterrence of hackers within weakly fortified environments?  The proposed research represents a collaboration between criminologists, psychologists, and computer security experts and will evaluate criminological theories within cyberspace using, in addition to survey data and experimental design, detailed network and target computer data drawn from the real time operation of an organization network. 

Intellectual Merit 
A major goal of this project is to move toward a new integrated social science perspective on cybercrime. The pathway to such integration is through the social ecology of a local computing environment. The research proposed here, which simultaneously examines the characteristics of users-victims, offenders-hackers and the computing environment where they interact, will provide a rare opportunity to integrate these situational components.  In addition to providing new insights into criminology theory, the proposed research will provide detailed information on the interaction of hackers and users within the context of a weakly fortified computing environment.

Broader Impact 
We believe that our ecological approach to cyber security will offer useful insights for ways of improving online security by identifying those system configurations that discourage victim behaviors that are especially likely to result in attacks and deter attackers from malicious activities.  Bringing information together from potential victims and offenders within the world of an operating computer environment will allow the development of more efficient safety programs and strategies and has the potential to increase the security of computer systems and strengthen users' confidence and trust in their systems and the cyber environment more generally.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this research was to study the ecology of cyber security in a bazaar computing environment and to derive human-based security solutions from the study. Three major questions were examined:

  1. How do we prevent users within weakly fortified environments (WFE) from engaging in risky online behavior?
  2.  How deterrable are hackers?
  3. If hackers are deterrable (to some degree) and user behavior is modifiable (to some degree), then what is the optimal scenario in which IT management can maximize both in a WFE?

 

To answer these questions, we employed criminological theories within cyberspace

using, in addition to survey data and experimental design, detailed network and target computer data drawn from the real-time operation of an organization network. Findings from our project reveal that:

  1. Computer users’ situational awareness and offline self-protective practices are negatively associated with their likelihood to apply online self-protective behaviors. Therefore, future training efforts should emphasize the need to apply both types of behaviors in computer users’ workflow.
  2. Hackers respond to deterring stimulus (warning, surveillance) in an attacked computer system and behave significantly different in “deterring” computing environments than a non-deterring environment.
  3. Based on these findings, and a need assessment survey we administrated among a sample of IT managers, we believe that IT managers should develop policies and design the computing environments in such way that will “nudge” hackers away from an attacked system, while at the same time, support the implementation of both offline and online self-protective behaviors among computer users.  

 

The project involved the work of both undergraduate and graduate students from the department of criminology and criminal justice, the James Clark School of engineering and the Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Response to terrorism (i.e. START) in the University of Maryland. The PIs collaborated with students and developed research papers that were published in conferences and top criminological journals. We also developed a simulation and new course on cybersecurity that we hope will support future learners and practitioners effort to improve their knowledge and skills on cybersecurity.
